Description: Fragment of floor of North Ionian black-figured pottery plate, very worn and battered. Underside reserved with sets of three light grooves; on the floor, standing on an exergue line, feline to right, its rear legs and a bit of its belly preserved; incised rosettes as filler; added red on the thigh of the feline, on alternate petals of one of the rosettes, and on an object, probably the forepart of the lion, at the right.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Venit attributed this to Attica with hesitation.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 86 no. 288 pl. 64)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.683)
